fileDesc.extent: [information about file size goes here, information about extent of physical item comes later]

body.p:
Jacob Voorsanger,
Box 319.
Houston, Texas, 188
Houston, Texas, Dec. 22 1883
Rev. S. Morais, My dear Sir

Your kind and welcome
favor of the 9th of this month reached me in due
course of mail, but upon its arrival I was as yet
scarcely strong enough to send you a suitable reply.
I have been, if not "sick unto death" so very near
to it that I prayed [Hebrew]! I felt
myself in grave danger, though my good Doctor
derided the ^ idea. After delirium came weakness,
but I am now, thanks to our Father in Heaven, en
tirely restored, and feel my old vigorous strength
gradually, though a little slowly, returning. I
thank you for your kind sympathy.

I proceed to reply to your letter [Hebrew] etc.
I was, indeed, myself under the impression
that I would be called to a larger field of
usefulness. Results proved my impressions
erroneous. I never felt any disappointment
at not obtaining the position in question, much
as that may seem a paradox, for I am known
to be ambitious. The fact is, I felt myself
hardly prepared to enter a field of such

Jacob Voorsanger,
Box 319.
Houston, Texas, 188

magnitude. I still need, perhaps not as much the
scholastic training, as the earnestness of settled
manhood and the deliberateness that proceeds
from settled convictions. I am still a very young
man, more fit to sit at the feet of masters
and to learn, than to teach multitudes. I have
never known that my leaving college two years before
my time was a fatal error until the world began
to test my knowledge and my activity. I have, to the
full extent of my power, supplied these lost[?] years
by ten years of hard study and the severest
self-application, and yet I have done myself
not as much good in these many years as
my teachers, Heaven bless them, could have
done in two. Well, though I left college a
raw recruit, I have, I think, not been un
worthy of the men, who when I sat under
them in the [Hebrew] thought more of me
than I ever will become. In the days after
my illness, when I was weak and helpless,
the scenes of my youth came back to me
with unwanted force, and a longing to see
the dear old faces came over me, that for

Jacob Voorsanger,
Box 319.
Houston, Texas, 188

a few hours made me melancholic. At thirty one
is not so hardened yet as to think with indif-
ference about home, about father and mother,
and the scenes of youth. Well, my illness had one good
result, and I thank God for it. I promised, if
I could never be what my old teachers thought
I would become, that in my allotted sphere,
and with the light I have, I would work, un-
ceasingly for the good of Israel. It was
their intelligent training that made me what
I am, and, as one of them wrote me lately,
rather quaintly, "even a reformer can show
that he fears God."--But to return, Houston
is really getting too small for me, but it
will do for some time to come. Small con-
gregations, I have learned, are excellent
training-schools. One learns to curb his
temper, to subdue his passion, and to
meet everybody [Hebrew]. The pettiness
of provincial sentiment was unknown
to me, born and raised in a metropolis,
until I came to this city with its 30,000
inhabitants. But on the other hand provin-

Jacob Voorsanger,
Box 319.
Houston, Texas, 188

cial cities give one more encouragement than is
expected. In my case I was received with much
confidence. My faults were soon known, yet the
congregation bore with them. I was encouraged in
developing my peculiar aptitude for speaking,
and I found generous friends who [Hebrew] prais-
ed me, and to my face told me all my failings.
So that, after six years residence in Texas,
I may have become a rustic, but the rough
edges worn off and the "greenness" of youth
and inexperience has disappeared. I love
Houston and its people, for both have been very
kind and generous to me. And I sometimes
feel that I ought to permanently remain
here, were it not that ambition whispers
in my ear that I deserve a larger field
and more honor and remuneration. But
you honor me, indeed, when you say, that
you have confidence in my little ability.
Such an expression from you makes me
really believe that one day I will find
myself where I wish to be.

Jacob Voorsanger,
Box 319.
Houston, Texas, 188

The lateness of the hour last night—it was
[Hebrew] caused me to break off. I have fol-
lowed your interesting account of the difference
between Kabbalism, Chassidism and Tradition-
alism, and I fully and entirely endorse your
conclusions, but yet, I hope you will pardon me
when I say, that you somewhat misapprehend
my position. Let me, briefly, explain to you what
it is, for if you do me the honor to speak to me
[Hebrew] I speak to you [Hebrew].
I remember, one day, when we were walking
along seventh street to your synagogue, I
affirmed, in the exuberance of my youth
and, speaking with the reverence you had
inspired me, that I would never abandon
the teachings of my masters nor lend my
aid to reform. I often think of this affir-
mation and it gives me severe mental
exercise. I am ever trying to reconcile
my present position with my personal
and private convictions. I am to-day
as conservative as I ever was. When

Jacob Voorsanger,
Box 319.
Houston, Texas, 188

One who was inhaled the air of a Beth
Hammedrash in Amsterdam cannot be
otherwise. I am really no reformer in the
sense your German rationalists apply
the term. But I have come to that point,
where I make a distinction between forma-
lism and pure religion. There I have, I know,
departed from the beaten track. I was
taught that Talmudical Rabbinism was
the logical and historical sequence of proph-
etic Judaism, and that the subsequent Rab-
binism of the Rishonim and Aharonim,
and Kabbalism as well, were the logical
outcomings of Talmudism, to use that
term for a moment. My personal investiga-
tions have overthrown the position that was
impressed on me in my youth. I see now in
the legal Halachas of the Talmud nothing
that should be, or ought to be, binding
on citizens of any country, for they are
the sum total of the legal codex by
which a Jewish Senate governed the
second Jewish commonwealth. Am

Jacob Voorsanger,
Box 319.
Houston, Texas, 188

I correct? The fact that the Rabbis built
their legal conclusions upon Scriptural
inferences is nothing to me; I need not tell
you how often a single iota is made to be
the warrant for Scriptural authority. As to
the Agadis portion of the Talmud I concede
that we cannot do without it. It explains
the Bible. Now, will you not grant me that
the post-Talmudic Rabbinism was the
sequence of a doctrine that the legal deci-
sions of the Talmud were binding for
all times? The Jews in their Ghetto, given
the right to be governed according to their own
laws, made the Talmud the basis of their
jurisprudence, and piles upon piles of
[Hebrew] are nothing but commentaries
upon, or revisions of Ghetto jurisprudence.
Am I right? And then this Talmudical
jurisprudence was, like as in the theocra-
tic commonwealth, made a parcel
of religion, and [Hebrew] was
replaced by the [Hebrew] for all who
were recreant to their forced condition.

Jacob Voorsanger,
Box 319.
Houston, Texas, 188

of things. Subsequently Kabbalism arose, and
you will permit me to treat it, I know, as the
invention of a crafty Spaniard, not as a
revelation to Shimon ben Jokai. What good
has it done? It changed the rest of Rabbinism
to the quagmire of stagnation. It did what
the Rabbis in and out of Palestine had never
done and always denounced, it enslaved
reason and made superstition rule. It intro-
duced elements in Judaism, far more dan-
gerous than the false dogmas of trini-
tarianism. What wonder that it became
the enemy of Rabbinism? It made the
doctrine [Hebrew] the butt of contempt
and ridicule, in that it taught such
unreasonable, unnatural anticipations,
that multitudes became crazed. It dethroned
the one God, our [Hebrew] And
made of Him, an nonentity not even cap-
able, [Hebrew] of creating the world! It
dethroned God, I say, and the [Hebrew] be-
came the ruling powers. What stupendous
folly! The pure lines of our [Hebrew] chan-

Jacob Voorsanger,
Box 319.
Houston, Texas, 188

ged into a mystic vocabulary teaching all
manner of unreasonable things, the teach
ings of the Rabbis ridiculed, or made to
mean what the Kabbalah intended--
what good, pray, has this false science ever
done? And here I will prove that my defi-
nitions were correct. Before Spa the Kabbalah
became powerful, Spanish Judaism was
extinct. In Italy and the Orient it found teach-
ers before it ever reached Germany. When
chassidism emanated from it, it was as
the re reconciliation between Rabbinism with
Kabbalism. Is this right? The traditi...tional
ritual—here traditionalism comes in--
shared the fate of the Scriptures—it became
a footstone for the Kabbalists. Every bened-
iction, every prayer was made to mean
what they thought; bows and bendings of
the body, and mysterious bits of [Hebrew] and
God knows what else when introduced until
two centuries after its birth Kabbalism
had engrafted itself on Rabbinism and
the two—united--gave the our fathers

Jacob Voorsanger,
Box 319.
Houston, Texas, 188

a religion no different from the Law of
Moses, from the religion of Isaiah, as is Heav
the earth different from Heaven. I admit it
suited the times, unfortunately. Exclusion
from without fostered the generation of
narrow-mindedness & superstition with-
in. But why must this continue in our
age?

And withal I know full well that
we cannot think of Judaism without
Rabbinism. For Judaism as we know
it was only defined when the [Hebrew]
and their successors commenced their
beneficent work. But that intelligent
Rabbinism that explains Judaism
gives it strength; the chassidism
that was the daughter of the mediae-
val Rabbinism and Kabbalism only
teaches forms and prayers and rites, and
cares not a particle whether you believe
in the one or the triune God, so long
you subscribe to the unutterable

Jacob Voorsanger,
Box 319.
Houston, Texas, 188

nonsense of the [Hebrew] and kindred books.
My position, to myself, is very plain. I believe
in God, in [Hebrew] in [Hebrew], in [Hebrew] though
not in a personal [Hebrew]. I hope and believe in
[Hebrew] and in the continuation of life
in the hereafter. My opinions are fixed on
these things, God only knows after how much
anguish, and doubt, and mental suffering.
But—forgive me-- I cannot return to[^] the Rab-
binism of my teachers. It sickens me, for
I think it false. Can I not teach these
doctrines with the fire of personal con-
victions and the aid of Talmud and
Medrash? For I draw the distinction,
as I have explained, between Hal-
acha and Agada. Now—in so far as
reform is merely a setting up of personal
hubbies[?]—I disbelieve in it. I have organ
and choir and family pews, but I read
in Hebrew, and, as you well know, my
Visitor is as conservative a paper
as exists in America. Your orthodoxy
is indeed so intelligent that one need

Jacob Voorsanger,
Box 319.
Houston, Texas, 188

not go to the reformers, and this explains
the strength and perpetuity of the organiza-
tion of which you are the honored pastor.
But—can one like me, who has learned to
think—be content with the Polish Beth
Hammedrash or with Lehman's affect-
ed, unreasonable and illogical neo-
othodoxy?

I must close, and close abruptly. I had much more to write to you, but my letter
is already the seize of a respectable address.
Forgive me if it tires you, I have no confi-
dential friend in this whole wide country
but yourself. The others are good friends, but
they cannot teach me. You can, and I
know you will. You are my senior by thirty
years, my superior in everything else, will
you not tell me, whether I am right or
wrong in my statements?

With best wishes
faithfully yours
Jacob Voorsanger
